awd_titl_txt: AGEP-KAT: Adopting Evidence Based Strategies to Improve Academic Climate and the Success of Underrepresented Doctoral Students in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is supported by the Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program and is a Knowledge Adoption and Translation (AGEP-KAT) award.  The AGEP program funds KAT projects to expand the adoption and/or adaptation of research findings and evidence-based strategies and practices related to the participation and success of underrepresented minorities (URMs) in STEM graduate education, postdoctoral training, and academic STEM careers at all types of institutions of higher education.  This award funds activities at the University of Pittsburgh's Swanson School of Engineering to adopt and adapt strategies and practices employed by the University of Maryland Baltimore County's (UMBC) Meyerhoff Scholars Program and the NSF-funded PROMISE AGEP Maryland project.  This KAT project is designed to improve the transitions of URM students, who are US citizens, into doctoral engineering programs at the University of Pittsburgh and to ensure their successful completion by employing evidence-based strategies for student and faculty engagement and fostering an inclusive academic climate for URM doctoral students.  The success of the adoption and adaption process will directly benefit a cohort of US citizens who are URM doctoral students majoring in engineering fields.  Results from this KAT will also inform engineering graduate programs across the nation about how to adapt effective strategies for faculty engagement, for improving academic climate change, and for ensuring URM doctoral student success.

The project team will explore the following faculty-specific objectives as they work to address the project goal: Improving faculty engagement with students, advancing their awareness of the barriers and problems the student experience, and developing a shared vision regarding the success of URM graduate students within the school of engineering.  Student-focused objectives include:  Adapting and implementing the evidence-based strategies being adopted, enhancing professional and educational skills, and increasing the number of students who are retained and graduated in engineering doctoral programs.  The team will consult with administrative leaders from UMBC and The Pennsylvania State University who, as part of the project's evaluation process, will provide feedback regarding the adoption, adaption, implementation and assessment of the faculty and student strategies.  Products are expected to include publications in peer-reviewed journals.

PITT STRIVE Program Outcomes Report

 

PITT STRIVE Program (PSP) was funded by the National Science Foundation AGEP-KAT program, grant # 1434012. Prior to PSP, the strategy to improve the success of underrepresented minority (URM) PhD students (e.g., African America, Hispanic American, and Native American) in engineering at the University of Pittsburgh Swanson School of Engineering (SSoE) was focused on mentoring the students to fit the faculty and department cultures and expectations. The approach was through the lens of "deficit-based models", which assumes or fits URM groups to those that lack preparation or are deficit compared to the majority population. This approach created negative stereotypes and barriers to URM students aspiring for PhD in STEM. Understanding the distinguishing characteristics of the PITT engineering culture that needed to change to address the identified inequalities was the starting point in our theory of change. Thus, the primary goal of PSP was to transform SSoE climate and culture to reinforce the foundational values of diversity, equity, and inclusion as essential to advancing teaching, research, and community engagement to enriching  students' experiences. We postulated that understating and addressing these barriers to students' success from a school, department, and faculty standpoints, would foster an inclusive community and academic culture of excellence that would propel URM students to successful and timely completion of their doctoral studies. Specific objective to achieve the stated goal included a focus on access,  retention, and timely PhD graduation in all fields of engineering; improving faculty awareness of the impediments to URM success in doctoral programs;  promoting a shared vision among vested faculty regarding the success of URM students; and promoting  a systemic inclusive academic culture and climate that support the success of URM doctoral students.

Intellectual Merit: The PSP advanced our   understating of the barriers to URM success and evidence-based strategy to change the environmental climate and academic culture of  the school, department, and faculty and  foster an inclusive community to support URM students’ success.  Specifically, PSP:

  • Created a replicable implementation model that transforms engineering graduate academic culture and climate for excellence and evidenced-based strategies on how the model can be adopted/adapted by an institution X.
  • Transformed the climate and culture to reinforce the foundational value of diversity, equity, and inclusion to enrich students' experiences.
  • Advanced our understanding of barriers to URM PhD success and how to achieve a systemic inclusive academic culture and climate that support the success of URM doctoral students.
  • Created a systemic culture of excellence that allowed URM PhD students to thrive with early success in passing their PhD qualify exams, record of publication, and high retention rate  comparable or higher than those for majority students.  
  • PSP created and demonstaed an implementation model for successul adaptation of UMBC Meyerfoff/PROMISE Programs

Broader Impact: The PSP implementation model led to the desired impacts for the increased number of URM PhDs and faculty professional development. Specifically, PSP

  • Has been transformational in increasing URM PhD enrollment from less than 5% to over 9.1%, enhancing the academic culture and community that have contributed to 27 URM PhDs in the last seven years, and significantly increased the number of faculty with a shared vision for the school's diversity and inclusion goals. Specifically,
    • STRIVE Scholars average GPA >3.75; 100% pass qualifying exams within first two years.
    • URM PhD retentions = 89% > non-URM
    • PITT STRIVE Graduates: 80% in industry; 20% in academia; 2 scholars have transitioned into tenure track positions (Dr. Katrina Knight @ University of Pittsburgh, SSoE and Dr. Sossena Wood @ CMU Engineering)
    • Number of peer-refereed publications =6
  • Created faculty and leadership receptivity to DEI values and the association of STRIVE students with excellence, resulting in increased number of faculty desiring more STRIVE scholars.
  • Increased faculty comfort level in mentoring URM students, unified around a shared vision to improve the culture of graduate engineering education.
  • Successfully adapted/adopted major program aspects of University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC) Meyerhoff undergraduate program and PROMISE Graduate programs and added several activities such as annual retreat and  Future Faculty Discovery Development Program
  • Impacted faculty as individuals, such as additional professional development opportunities to aid students in being successful in research and learning graduate school, noting,
    • “It seems like the program helps them have more successful outcomes like higher graduation rates, good GPA, they're more likely to stick with it and not drop out.”
    • Positive connection with their students and seeing value in other’s perspectives:
      • “I do credit the program with allowing me to see that there's just different backgrounds, different sets of experiences, and I don't know them all…To the best of my abilities I try to let them know that.. I have the capability to change.”
      •  “The more I've gotten to know PITT STRIVE Scholars, the more I feel the URM students have an opportunity that we are delighted to give them and mutually beneficial.”
